sections.title: Straight teeth — without fixed braces
sections.body:
Clear aligners are a discreet way to improve crowding, spacing and bite alignment. We plan your treatment carefully, monitor progress closely, and keep the focus on long-term stability — not rushed cosmetic changes.

We start with a clinical assessment and a digital scan. From there, we map what can be moved safely, what should be left alone, and what would benefit from preparation (for example, bite adjustment or selective shaping).

If aligners are suitable, you’ll wear a series of custom trays that guide small, controlled movements over time. You’ll know what the process involves, what the limitations are, and what retention will look like before we begin.
bullets: Discreet way to improve crowding, spacing and bite alignment
Clear limits and retention explained before treatment
Focused on long-term stability, not rushed changes

sections.title: How clear aligners work
sections.body:
Aligners move teeth using gentle, staged forces. The key is planning the right sequence — and knowing when not to push.

Each aligner is worn for a set period, then replaced with the next one in the series. Small steps add up to meaningful change.

Some cases need small attachments (to help grip and guide movement) or minor reshaping between teeth. We’ll only recommend what’s clinically justified and explain why.

Aligners can be excellent for mild–moderate crowding and spacing, and in some cases more complex changes — but not every bite is a safe aligner case. If fixed braces or a different approach would be more predictable, we’ll tell you.

sections.title: Support for mild to moderate alignment needs
items: Often a good fit for: crowding, spacing, mild bite issues, relapse after braces, one tooth out of line
May need a different approach: significant skeletal bite problems, severe rotations, cases needing larger jaw correction
You’ll also need: good gum health, committed wear-time, willingness to wear retainers afterwards

sections.title: Steady steps with clear expectations
items: 1. Consultation & suitability check (teeth, bite, gums)
2. Digital scan + photos (and x-rays if needed for planning)
3. Plan review: what we’re aiming to change — and what we’re not
4. Aligners fitted + wear-time guidance
5. Review appointments to confirm tracking and comfort
6. Finishing & refinement (if required)
7. Retention: retainers to hold the result

sections.title: Digital planning that respects your bite
sections.body:
We use digital scans and planning to visualise movements and check how your teeth will meet as things change.

Alignment isn’t just cosmetic. A well-planned result should look natural and function comfortably — so we balance aesthetics with bite stability.

Where appropriate, we can combine aligners with whitening or edge-bonding as a separate step — but only once alignment is stable and you’ve had time to “live in” the new bite.

sections.title: Comfort-first guidance with clear responsibilities
items: Keep aligners clean: rinse, brush gently, avoid hot water
Remove to eat and drink anything except water
Expect mild pressure at changeover — tell us if pain is sharp or persistent
Keep up routine hygiene and hygiene appointments
Protect results with retainers as prescribed

sections.title: Not sure if aligners are right for you?
sections.strapline: We’ll assess your bite, gum health and tooth position, then talk you through options in plain English. If clear aligners are suitable, we’ll explain the likely timeline, what the day-to-day feels like, and what retention will involve — before you commit.

faqs.question: How long does clear aligner treatment take?
faqs.answer: It depends on what we’re correcting and how well the aligners track. Some cases are a few months; others take longer. After an assessment and scan, we can give you a realistic estimate and explain the variables.

faqs.question: Do I have to wear them all the time?
faqs.answer: Aligners only work when they’re worn as prescribed. You’ll remove them for eating and drinking (except water), and you’ll need a consistent routine for best predictability.

faqs.question: Will aligners fix my bite as well as straighten my teeth?
faqs.answer: Sometimes, yes — within limits. Cosmetic alignment and bite correction overlap, but they’re not the same thing. We’ll check whether your bite goals are achievable with aligners or whether another approach would be more predictable.

faqs.question: Will I need attachments?
faqs.answer: Many patients do. Attachments are small, tooth-coloured shapes that help aligners grip and guide specific movements. We’ll only recommend them if they improve control and predictability.

faqs.question: Are aligners painful?
faqs.answer: Most people feel pressure, especially when switching to a new aligner. That’s normal. Sharp pain, bite changes that feel “wrong”, or anything that doesn’t settle should be reviewed.

faqs.question: What happens when I finish?
faqs.answer: Retention is essential. Teeth can drift over time, so retainers are used to hold your result. We’ll plan retention from the start and explain your options.

faqs.question: Can aligners be combined with whitening or bonding?
faqs.answer: Often, yes — but sequencing matters. We usually align first, stabilise the bite, then consider whitening and/or edge bonding if appropriate. We’ll advise based on your enamel, bite and goals.

faqs.question: What if my teeth stop tracking?
faqs.answer: If an aligner isn’t fitting as planned, we’ll assess why and adjust the plan. That may include extra wear-time guidance, a review appointment, or refinement aligners if needed.

sections.title: A calm way to decide
sections.body:
The right plan is the one that’s predictable, healthy, and fits your life — not just the one that looks fastest on paper.

We’ll show you what aligners can realistically achieve in your case, and what they can’t.

We’ll talk about trade-offs: speed vs stability, aesthetics vs bite comfort, and what retention will require long-term.

If you’d be better served by fixed braces, restorative work, or simply doing nothing right now, we’ll say so.
